text: i had an idea that i thought might be helpful: #fridayfails … a quick story about a career-related failure and something you learned from it. i’ll go first:

elements.text: i had an idea that i thought might be helpful: #fridayfails … a quick story about a career-related failure and something you learned from it. i’ll go first:

text: ~5 years i decided i was done working for other companies and wanted to work on my own. i had big ideas about how to create a cool freelance career, so i quit my job (which was a good job that i actually really enjoyed) and started freelancing. i mismanaged SO many things: i didn’t charge enough, i realized that i didn’t really want to spend all day every day writing, i was bad about chasing people around for payments, i worked more than ever bc i was stressed about money, i took on work i didn’t want to do bc i was afraid to increase my rates. it was a disaster and i realized that  actually having a job wasn’t so bad! luckily the company took me back. my big takeaway was that freelance work is harder than it looks and that people who do it well are disciplined, confident and hardworking.

elements.text: ~5 years i decided i was done working for other companies and wanted to work on my own. i had big ideas about how to create a cool freelance career, so i quit my job (which was a good job that i actually really enjoyed) and started freelancing. i mismanaged SO many things: i didn’t charge enough, i realized that i didn’t really want to spend all day every day writing, i was bad about chasing people around for payments, i worked more than ever bc i was stressed about money, i took on work i didn’t want to do bc i was afraid to increase my rates. it was a disaster and i realized that  actually having a job wasn’t so bad! luckily the company took me back. my big takeaway was that freelance work is harder than it looks and that people who do it well are disciplined, confident and hardworking.

text: i could see going down that path again one day but taking a _very_ different approach

elements.text: i could see going down that path again one day but taking a
very
different approach

text:
here's the one that still haunts my dreams:

a few years ago, we had a law firm as a client. they had call tracking via marchex, and we were migrating them to callrail. we had to deliver a spreadsheet to callrail with the current tracking number in one column and actual number in the next.

neurotic as i am, i quintuple checked the numbers to make sure they were right. what i _neglected_ to realize was that the order they were listed in marchex (real, tracking) was the inverse of the spreadsheet (tracking, real).

when callrail implemented the changes, it made the firm completely unreachable at _all_ of their offices in four states (no matter what number you called). it took the phone company _weeks_ to get all their numbers back.

morals of the story:

1. when you're QAing something, step back and make sure you're QAing _all_ the things that could go wrong. 
2. don't sacrifice performance for measurement. they _did not care_ about measuring phone calls, but we thought it was a way for us to show/prove value as an SEO agency. they _did_ care about all their phone lines going dead.

text:
#fridayfail: Eight years ago I left a director position at NBC to launch a startup men's publication.

There were a few warning signs that the endeavor was going to be cursed:

1. The VC wanted to personally run the company, which is *rarely* a good idea. VCs are not operators. :warning: 
2. The CEO had never managed anything in his life :warning:
3. They offered 25% less than I was making, and wouldn't budge :warning: 
But I believed mightily in the publication's value prop, so I took the pay cut to be the EIC. It was a great job for two years. And then the investment capital started running out. Which caused significant consternation among the employees. So then I, in my frustration with leadership, said some indelicate things. So I got fired. And I deserved it.

But I learned some valuable lessons. One, I learned to heed my own intuition about who I work with. If I have qualms about them, those qualms probably aren't going to go away over time. Two, I learned that I needed to make a deliberate decision when valuing compensation and opportunity.  At times I was frustrated at my relatively low pay, and that frustration leaked into my work relationships. Don't let that happen! We all need to be responsible to our own choices, and not blame others for our situation—I failed in that regard, and that's a big lesson learned.

It all worked out in the end.  After being fired, I started consulting, which proved to be much more remunerative and enjoyable. That led to my current agency gig, which I very much enjoy.

text:
5-6 years ago before working in content/marketing, I was working in my first role at a tech company. I was doing sales, and we weren’t growing fast enough. I had a potential customer who was enamored with the _idea_ of what the product did, but would need a bit of shoe-horning to get it to work for them.

I figured out how I would set it up if I was them, but knew in the pit of my stomach, it would be a stretch. I did numerous calls with the buyer explaining the how this _could work_ but would not be a great fit for what the software was designed for and they decided to go for it anyway.

I was enticed because this would be the largest customer on board and might help with more traction. But we ended up spending way more money supporting them than they ever paid us.

*Lessons:* 
1. If it’s not a good fit, don’t let the customer buy. You’ll both end up disappointed at the end of the day.
2. Be careful when there’s a lot of money at stake, it can easily blind you.
